task.title: Apply minimalism to your tasks
task.shortdesc: Minimalism, when applied to documentation, creates clean, usable procedures.

context.p: The idea behind minimalism is that you provide the right information in the right place and with the right format. Everything else is removed (sometimes to another topic), leaving a clean, distilled topic that includes only useful but essential information. Minimalist documentation is easy to follow, quick to read, and amazingly helpful.
You can apply minimalism to all your topic types; however, when you're beginning, it's easiest to apply minimalism to tasks.

step.cmd: Make sure your task is oriented on a user goal.
step.info: If you have content that is important but not directly related to the goal, put it in another topic.

step.cmd: Edit each step so that it contains only the command for the reader to perform.
step.info: Additional information that is pertinent to a particular step can be placed in the instruction section.

step.cmd: Put information that applies to the entire task in the appropriate section.

dlentry.dd: Things the reader must do before they can even start the first step.
Why the reader would perform the task. Usually, this is a description of the business goal you are writing for.
The result of the entire task.
What the reader should do after they have finished the task.

substep.cmd: Edit out words that do not add to the meaning of your content.
Put supporting content in concept or reference topics.
Remove any repetition; you only need to say something once.

step.info: When there is a step where readers are likely to run into a problem, add information on how they can recover in the instruction section.

step.cmd: Review the topic heading and introduction to ensure they are still accurate.
